We call on all employees of big technology & media companies to follow the lead of Trans* Netflix by holding their employers accountable for the social impact of their decisions. Together, we can make a safer, more inclusive future for everyone. 8/9

-We affirm the importance of representation for trans people, especially BIPOC, in high-level leadership roles (Director, VP etc.) at all companies, but particularly in big tech & media companies where decisions could disproportionately affect the safety of vulnerable people. 4/9
-We support the right of every trans and non-binary person to work in a safe place that is free from transphobic imagery and references. 3/9

...their work at a fair wage, w/out fear of abuse, retaliation or discrimination. When Google went public in 2004, it said it would do ‚Äúgood things for the world even if we forgo some short-term gains.‚Äù Its motto used to be ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be evil.‚Äù We‚Äôll live by that motto. 22/24

We care deeply about what we build and what it‚Äôs used for. We are responsible for the tech we bring into the world. & we recognize that its implications reach far beyond the walls of Alphabet. Our union will work to ensure that workers know what they‚Äôre working on, & can do 21/24

Everyone at Alphabet ‚Äî from bus drivers to programmers, from salespeople to janitors ‚Äî plays a critical part in developing our tech. But right now, wealthy executives define what the company produces & how workers are treated. This isn‚Äôt the company we want to work for. 20/24

...even though they often do the exact same work. They are also more likely to be Black or brown ‚Äî a segregated employment system that keeps half of the company‚Äôs work force in second-class roles. Our union will seek to undo this grave inequity. 19/24

Our union will be open to all Alphabet workers, regardless of classification. About half of the workers at Google are temps, vendors or contractors. They are paid lower salaries, receive fewer benefits, and have little job stability compared with full-time employees... 18/24

We want Alphabet to be a company where workers have a meaningful say in decisions that affect us and the societies we live in. As union members, we have created an elected leadership and representative structure with dues-paying members. 17/24
Yet time & again, company leaders have put profits ahead of our concerns. We‚Äôre joining together ‚Äî temps, vendors, contractors, and full-time employees ‚Äî to create a unified worker voice. 16/24

We are the workers who built Alphabet. We write code, clean offices, serve food, drive buses, test self-driving cars & do everything needed to keep this behemoth running. We joined Alphabet bc we wanted to build technology that improves the world. 15/24

It‚Äôs not enough. Today, we‚Äôre building on years of organizing efforts at Google to create a formal structure for workers. So far, 226 of us have signed union cards w/ @CODE_CWA ‚Äî the first step in winning a recognized bargaining unit. In other words, we are forming a union. 14/24

For a handful of wealthy executives, this discrimination & unethical working environment are working as intended, at the cost of workers w/ less institutional power, especially Black, brown, queer, trans, disabled, and women workers. 13/24
Alphabet continues to crack down on those who dare to speak out, & keep workers from speaking on sensitive & publicly important topics, like antitrust & monopoly power. 12/24

To those who are skeptical of unions or believe that tech companies are more innovative w/out unions, we point out that these and other larger problems persist. Discrimination/harassment continue. 11/24

hourly wage, parental leave, & health insurance after employee outcry. Forced arbitration for claims of sexual harassment ended after the walkout‚Äîalbeit only for full-time emps, not contractors. A few months later, Google ended forced arb (@endforcedarb) for all emp claims. 10/24

Workers have mobilized against these abuses before. Organized workers forced executives to drop Project Maven, the company‚Äôs AI program w/ the Pentagon, & Project Dragonfly, its plan to launch a censored search engine in China. Some of Alphabet‚Äôs subcontractors won a $15 min 9/24

In response, thousands of our colleagues organized, demanding an explanation. Both of us have heard from colleagues ‚Äî some new, some with over a decade at the company ‚Äî who have decided that working at Alphabet is no longer a choice they can make in good conscience. 8/24

Most recently, Timnit Gebru, a leading artificial intelligence researcher & one of the few Black women in her field, said she was fired over her work to fight bias. Her offense? Conducting research critical of large-scale AI models and being critical of existing D&I efforts. 7/24

They have developed AI for use by the Department of Defense & profited from ads by a hate group. They have failed to make the changes necessary to meaningfully address our retention issues with people of color. 6/24

For far too long, thousands of us at Google ‚Äî & other subsidiaries of Alphabet, Google‚Äôs parent company ‚Äî have had our workplace concerns dismissed by executives. Our bosses have collaborated w/ repressive govs around the world. 5/24

...and ‚ÄúUnfair workplaces create unfair platforms.‚Äù
We‚Äôd had enough.
The 2 of us are software engineers, & we were recently elected exec chair & vice chair of @AlphabetWorkers, a group of >200 workers in the United States who believe our company‚Äôs structure needs to change. 4/24

People speaking at the protests that morning recounted their experiences of harassment & discrimination at the company. In San Francisco, a woman held a sign reading, ‚ÄúI reported & he got promoted.‚Äù Others read, ‚ÄúHappy to quit for $90 million, no sexual harassment required‚Äù 3/24

A week earlier, The New York Times reported that the company had paid tens of millions of dollars to two executives who had been accused of sexual misconduct toward our co-workers, staying silent about the alleged abuse and letting them walk away with no consequences. 2/24

In 6th grade I read a book about how Larry & Sergey created Google. I knew it was where I wanted to work one day.

Long thread, but hopefully useful! We look forward to working with you in the future ‚Äî remember, our DMs are open! When we fight together, we win together, and we‚Äôre by your side. [end of thread]

- Don‚Äôt feed the trolls.
You‚Äôll have them, we all do. It‚Äôs often best to just leave them be, as opposed to engaging. Don‚Äôt respond to their tweets, leave their DMs in your spam. You don‚Äôt want to end up accidentally elevating their voice by drawing attention to it.

- Never go into an interview on your movement w/o a goal.
Make sure you look into their past work before agreeing to an interview, on or off the record (or on background). We‚Äôve had reporters with one outlet in their Twitter bio turn out to be writing for a much different one.

- A quick DM is worth the effort, & you should keep your DMs open, as press will be looking to get in touch w/ you.
We've been boosted by politicians, workers at other companies, activists working on related movements, & more accounts w/ 1000s of followers. We return the favor.

3. Making sure your graphics meet the WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) color contrast standard. As you are making your graphics, utilize WebAIM‚Äôs contrast checker.
https://t.co/xeHsjA2y2f

2. Never posting a text screenshot w/o the same content as typical text. People often feel posting a screenshot is a great way to circumvent the char limit, not realizing they‚Äôre cutting off people who use screen readers (typically low vision or blind people) from the message.

- Make sure your content is accessible.
If you‚Äôre not adhering to accessibility best practices, you‚Äôre alienating so many people from your action. Plus, it‚Äôs just the right thing to do.

On Twitter, this looks like:
1. Adding alt-text to your images (https://t.co/NxSWOf3z3d)

Encourage people to post signs (it can just be a piece of paper with a sentence in Sharpie) in your hashtag, then retweet them. For a lower risk option, in case people are afraid to attach their account to the action, let people know they can DM you their signs to be posted.

Is someone making a speech? Video and post clips ‚Äî even better, post a transcript as additional tweets in the thread.

Is your action individually distributed, ie people logging out of an app at a specific time? Post a photo of the logout screen.

Photos create an emotional appeal, an air of relatability. They often spark emotions in people more than just written words.
Are you making signs? Document the sign making process.
Are people physically gathering somewhere? Take photos showing the size of the crowd.
In the case of #GoogleWalkout, there are a few iconic photos that emerged showcasing individuals, but the sheer size of the crowd was our main visual hook alongside catchy signs.

- Show don‚Äôt tell ‚Äî well, don‚Äôt just tell.
When possible, use visuals. This both gives the press images for their articles and helps provide a ‚Äúface‚Äù for the movement. It doesn‚Äôt need to be an actual face!

- Every post should have a purpose.
It can be tempting to share content for the sake of it, as it‚Äôs important not to go silent for a long time. That said, unless you‚Äôre intentionally expanding your scope make sure you‚Äôre not straying off message.

-There‚Äôs a time&place for different outlets.
Medium is your friend, but know when to go bigger. Press releases, this guide, etc, make sense for Medium. We‚Äôre speaking to our followers, which for us means tech workers & journalists. Judge your preferred outlet based on your goals.

Reporters were on the edge of their seats waiting for a new flood of photos when it hit 11am in another time zone, both from here and from other Google workers posting their own photos in the hashtag,  which we would RT. If your action lends itself to this at all, take advantage.

-Keep up momentum. Start a drumbeat.
#GoogleWalkout was a media success in large part because we walked out at 11am local time around the world. This supplied us with a steady stream of content over a multi-day period.

If you‚Äôre running a specific timeboxed campaign, however (#WalkoutYearInReview ‚Äî 48 tweets in 12 hours!) you'll want the free 30 day trial of the paid plan. If you ultimately don‚Äôt have use for the paid plan > the 30 days, don‚Äôt forget to cancel, as it‚Äôs not cheap.

We use Hootsuite as our social media manager, as it‚Äôs relatively simple and allows for lots of flexibility. There‚Äôs a free plan and a paid plan. The free plan lets you have up to 30 scheduled Tweets at a time, which should be enough!

Timing is important ‚Äî you want to be posting your most important content earlier in the day, earlier in the week, if at all possible. Avoid Friday afternoon drops, as you‚Äôre cutting yourself off from the press cycle.
Their main advertised benefit of cross-posting to multiple accounts often doesn‚Äôt apply, but it‚Äôs immensely helpful when it comes to scheduling tweets!

-Use a social media manager to handle multiple accounts and schedule posts. Be mindful of timing.
There are a few sites that allow you to manage all of your social media accounts from one place.

-All you need is Twitter ‚Äî usually.
Twitter is where tech movements specifically have thrived; beyond us, see @EthicalGooglers, @WayfairWalkout, @AmznForClimate, & more. Unless you‚Äôre using a social media management tool, lower engagement via Insta is rarely worth the effort.
Often, your demands are your messaging. If you‚Äôre bringing something to light, ie as a whistleblower, a quick summary of that content is your messaging.

-Formulate messaging and stay on it.
Develop your goals, convert them into words, and hammer them home whenever you see an opening. If people come away with one or two things from your post, what should they be? This is what you‚Äôll structure your content around.
An entire flyer as an icon isn‚Äôt a good move, though you‚Äôre often able to pull one image from it. https://t.co/I4xpNgEY5V is a great online version of Photoshop, and it‚Äôs free.

Your icon/banner, though less important, go a long way in giving your movement a polished look. Settle on a few colors and stick to them. If your icon has text, make sure it‚Äôs sparse & large enough to read.

We struggle to think of a situation where this is a better strategy than creating a new account, especially if your personal account doesn‚Äôt already have a very large following. Ego is where movements go to die ‚Äî don‚Äôt play into it! This is bigger than you now.
A common pitfall: organizers will occasionally try to use their own personal Twitter accounts to centralize a movement.

If what you‚Äôre organizing around can‚Äôt be succinctly summed up, go the @EthicalGooglers route and declare what you stand for. A bonus: that sort of handle can be reused if you end up needing to organize around additional, more separate issues.
An added benefit of this sort of handle? It can be used as your hashtag, as well, making your account easier to find.

We‚Äôll dive into those three a bit later, but let‚Äôs get started!

-Choose a memorable handle, hashtag, and icon/banner.
Your handle should ideally declare your movement/action in a word or two. We were able to grab @GoogleWalkout, and it‚Äôs served us well.

Thank you to everyone doing the work at Google, across the industry, and beyond. We‚Äôre proud to be a part of this movement. Onward!
Stay tuned to @GoogleWalkout on Twitter. Today from 11am-11pm EST, we‚Äôll be posting a comprehensive Year in Review. 
12/12
We refuse to be exploited, harassed, and passed over at work. And we refuse to contribute to products, policies, and initiatives that cause harm to others inside and outside the company. 11/12

We‚Äôre here, one year later, to make it clear: we‚Äôre committed to continuing for the long-term, organizing locally and connecting across global offices to continue building the strength we need to ensure real structural change at Google, and across the industry. 10/12

While it would have been nice if Google simply recognized the strength of our arguments, and met our common sense demands, history is clear: this is not how it works. But the growth of the movement, and the company‚Äôs pushback, is a sign that we‚Äôre winning. 9/12

...hoping to suppress legally protected organizing. They‚Äôve tried to crack down on worker speech, avoid important questions, and stop worker-led meetings. And they retaliated against organizers, prompting us to host a Town Hall that over 15,000 people at the company viewed. 8/12

...to take away workers‚Äô right to organize using corporate digital tools, e.g., email, mailing lists, chat rooms ‚Äî exactly what we used to organize the Walkout. Since then, Google has taken a page from the centuries-old anti-labor playbook... 7/12

...demanding an end to tech‚Äôs complicity in the climate crisis.
Surprising no one, Google executives don‚Äôt like this. While they publicly supported the walkout, two weeks later the company quietly filed a petition with the National Labor Relations Board asking them... 6/12

And beyond Google, Riot Games, Wayfair, & Tableau workers organized their own walkouts (solidarity!). And workers from Amazon, Microsoft, Google, & 10 other tech companies joined the Climate Strike together... 5/12

Since then, organizing has spread. Workers campaigned to end forced arbitration (& won for full time workers!); fought for fair treatment & better benefits for TVCs (& won!); they pushed back on Dragonfly (& won!), the Advanced Technology External Advisory Board (& won!)... 3/12

Since then, a movement has grown, at Google & across tech.
While worker dissent & labor organizing were happening well before, the Walkout was the first time we showed real power. Thousands of people stepped up to contribute, w/ hundreds of local organizers taking the lead. 2/12

Yesterday was my last day at Google. It's been a long, wild road, and I am thrilled to be officially stepping into my role as Co-director of @AINowInstitute full time at NYU. Here's what I wrote to my friends and colleagues who remain at Google https://t.co/RADFlWkay9

Holding Google accountable&ensuring a safe workplace will require tech worker organizers form strong alliances w/ independent researchers, journalists, & communities on the front lines. This has the added benefit of building more powerful organizing structures.

Onward!
Meredith

As such, people living in contexts well outside of Google are often in the best position to speak to the true impacts of Google‚Äôs tech ‚Äî whether it be the click-workers training data for AI models, or the communities most impacted by YouTube‚Äôs engagement-driven algorithm.

Build solidarity with those beyond the company
The application of Google‚Äôs tech goes well beyond the relatively homogeneous Google campuses (‚Äúbillions of users or none,‚Äù I‚Äôve heard many an exec opine).

Such a demand should be at the core of ethical organizing, and could be extended to ensure that the public is aware of where specific technologies that impact their lives and communities are being applied, and by whom.

And to uphold this right, Google‚Äôs infrastructures and processes need to adapt, providing a ‚Äúchain of title‚Äù from design through to application. This is also a structural requirement for meaningful accountability and compliance.

Demand to know what you‚Äôre working on/how it‚Äôs used:
Too often, those designing/developing technical systems don‚Äôt know how they‚Äôll be used, or by whom (see: Maven, Dragonfly, etc). The right to know what you‚Äôre working on, &how it‚Äôs applied, should be recognized as fundamental.
The public deserves to know how, and where, powerful technical systems are shaping their lives and opportunities.

Google needs worker-led structures that can ensure it‚Äôs safe to speak about the darker side of the company. These should include protections for whistleblowers who alert the public to dangerous or unethical projects that put them at risk.

Protect conscientious objectors & whistleblowers:
We‚Äôve seen too many reports of retaliation/punishment against those who speak up about unethical projects and toxic workplace conditions. This prevents necessary change and makes accountability impossible. 
https://t.co/yvJvJOLYog

In considering which structure best accomplishes these goals, I would advocate boldness, remembering that the labor protections we have were won through organizing and collective action, not the other way around.

And it means continuing to place equity concerns at the center of organizing, and including TVCs at the helm of decision-making ‚Äî the company (and ‚Äúthe future of work‚Äù) is moving in a direction where soon everyone but upper management will be a TVC.

It does mean continuing to build strong relationships with each other, and doing this in a way that recognizes both prior art and the significant, specific concerns plaguing the tech industry ‚Äî including its outsized influence on all other sectors.
This doesn‚Äôt mean letting an outside union ‚Äúorganize‚Äù Google and dictate worker concerns (this would be a bad model, in my view). In many places it‚Äôs quite possible to DIY a union.

Unionize ‚Äî in a way that works:
There are good unions and there are awful unions, but building structural power that will allow Google workers to hold leadership accountable is something worth doing. And generally, this is called a union.
In solidarity with all of you who will continue this essential work within Google, I‚Äôll close by offering an incomplete map of where I see future tech organizing moving:
I offer my unwavering support & love to those of you who continue to do amazing work here, & who have taken risks to support others.

The stakes are extremely high‚Äîthe use of AI for social control & oppression is emerging, even in the face of developers‚Äô best of intentions. We have a short window to act, to build in real guardrails for these systems before AI is built into our infrastructure & it‚Äôs too late.

And I‚Äôd be much sadder if I didn‚Äôt see many hundreds of Googlers establishing themselves as leaders, contributing their brilliance to organizing, and refusing to stand silent in the face of leadership‚Äôs dangerous complicity. Please, keep going!
Leaving Google is deeply emotional for me, and I don‚Äôt know all of the ways I‚Äôll miss it. I‚Äôm lucky because I get to continue my work at AI Now.

Organized tech workers ‚Äî you! ‚Äî have emerged as a force capable of making real change, pushing for public accountability, oversight, and meaningful equity. And this right when the world needs it most.
What began as an experiment ‚Äî can we apply labor organizing to address tech‚Äôs ethical crisis? ‚Äî became one of the most difficult and gratifying efforts I‚Äôve ever been involved in.

...and communicate this to the public. This has been an unqualified success, and we‚Äôve already had extraordinary impact across research and policy. The other part was to begin organizing: history shows that centralized power rarely concedes without collective action.

In the meantime, issues of AI, bias & inequity grew more urgent & I became increasingly worried.

Part of my response was to co-found the AI Now Institute at NYU w/ Kate Crawford, establishing a home for rigorous research to examine social implications of AI...

...colleagues. I have tried hard to offer evidence and pathways for positive structural change, but over time I realized that my presence ‚Äúat the table‚Äù was more about the appearance of an inclusive debate, rather than seriously contending with the problems in the company.

I‚Äôve had an amazing time here. I climbed my way from an entry level role in 2006 to an EST position as a researcher & public voice on AI issues. I marshalled & presented evidence in the service of more accountable technology. I‚Äôm proud of what I did&grateful to work w/ amazing...

Addressing these problems, & making sure AI is just, accountable, & safe, will require serious structural change to how technology is developed & how tech corps are run. Ethical principles and in-house ethical reviews are a positive step, but we need a lot more.
The AI industry & the tools it creates are already widening inequality, enriching the powerful and disadvantaging those who are struggling.

The AI field is overwhelmingly white and male, and as the Walkout highlighted, there are systems in place that are keeping it that way. This, while marginalized populations bear most of the risks of biased or harmful AI.
How this vast power is used ‚Äî who benefits and who bears the risk ‚Äî is one of the most urgent social and political (and yes, technical) questions of our time. And we have a lot of work to do.

I‚Äôm certain many in leadership ‚Äî who learned what Google was and why it was great over a decade ago ‚Äî don‚Äôt truly understand the direction in which Google is growing. Nor are they incentivized to.

The result is that Google, in the conventional pursuit of quarterly earnings, is gaining significant & largely unchecked power to impact our world (including in profoundly dangerous ways, such as accelerating the extraction of fossil fuels & deployment of surveillance tech).
This has helped propel Google‚Äôs entry into ‚Äúnew markets‚Äù ‚Äî healthcare, fossil fuels, city development and governance, transportation, & beyond.
The company has emerged as a global leader in AI (the result of some combination of strategy, luck, timing, & massive centralized data and compute resources).

This has been hard to accept, since this work urgently needs doing. Google is one of the most powerful organizations on the planet; I‚Äôve had the privilege to see it grow from a few thousand committed people to the behemoth it is today.

The reasons I‚Äôm leaving aren‚Äôt a mystery. I‚Äôm committed to the AI Now Institute, to my AI ethics work, and to organizing for an accountable tech industry ‚Äî and it‚Äôs clear Google isn‚Äôt a place where I can continue this work.

7/10 was my 13th Google anniversary, & today is my last day.
My exp. at Google shaped who I am & the path I‚Äôm on. It‚Äôs hard to overstate how grateful I am for the teachers, mentors & friends along the way, or how surreal this moment is. I still can‚Äôt imagine my badge not working.

"It is my greatest hope in leaving that people continue to speak up and talk to each other, stand up for one another and for what‚Äôs right, and keep building the collective voice. I hope that leadership listens. Because if they won‚Äôt lead, we will."
[18/18]

"I still think this place is magic, but now I locate much of its brilliance and goodness in the people, not in some amorphous idea of the ‚Äúculture‚Äù or what happens at TGIF every week. 
[17/18]

"Life is extremely short and realistically we only have a couple of years left until the world hurtles into climate apocalypse or some other paroxysm of our own doing. 
[16/18]

"...that makes it difficult to do my job or find another one. If I stayed, I didn‚Äôt just worry that there‚Äôd be more public flogging, shunning, and stress, I expected it. 
[15/18]

"The short explanation for my decision is my health: I‚Äôm having another baby in the fall (I acknowledge there‚Äôs incredible privilege in being able to walk away from a job like this). I made the choice after heads of my department branded me w/ a kind of scarlet letter... 
14/18
"It pains me greatly to leave because I care so much about this company, its people, and the power it wields in the world (‚Äúhere lies Claire: she cared,‚Äù my epitaph, probably). [13/18]

"...who‚Äôs been Through It in any way: pushed out or punished for speaking up, gaslit, discriminated against, isolated, harassed. People are telling each other their stories. Refusing to acknowledge our humanity/engage w/ issues being raised‚Äîwell, that‚Äôs not very Googley. 
[12/18]

"But putting the huge looming questions aside (if it wasn‚Äôt retaliation, then what was it?), when they say ‚ÄúClaire‚Äôs experience didn‚Äôt happen,‚Äù they‚Äôre talking to everyone who thought my story sounded familiar, anyone... 
[11/18]

"That‚Äôs why I find it so depressing that leadership has chosen to just bluntly refute my story. They have a different version of what happened; that‚Äôs how this works. 
[10/18]

"These past few months have been unbearably stressful and confusing. But they‚Äôve been eye-opening, too: the more I spoke up about what I was experiencing, the more I heard, and the more I understood how universal these issues are. 
[9/18]

"It was the way that management answered the TGIF questions about the Andy Rubin payout‚Äìthe sidestepping, the jokes, the total lack of accountability‚Äìthat inspired me to call for the Walkout. 
[8/18]

"Google‚Äôs always had controversies and internal debates, but the ‚Äúhard things‚Äù had intensified, and the way leadership was addressing them suddenly felt different, cagier, less satisfying. 
[7/18]

"But when I got back to work after having my son Malcolm in 2017, it wasn‚Äôt me who was having an existential crisis. It was Google itself. The world had changed, dramatically altering the context of our work and the magnitude of our decisions, especially at YouTube. 
[6/18]

"Fast forward a few years and I‚Äôd moved to New York, cycled through Creative Lab and landed at YouTube. As I neared the ten-year mark, my first boss, Sally Cole, who‚Äôd left Google many years before, joked that I was surely due for an existential crisis. 
[5/18]

"...watching Larry and Sergey and TGIF in a kind of (half-a-beer-buzzed) state of rapture. Google‚Äôs lore, its leadership, its promise‚Äîthe whole thing lit me up, filled me with a sense of purpose, of inspiration, of privilege to be here. 
[4/18]

"I whizzed around campus on those primary-colored bikes. I dabbled in veganism. But the most potent sense-memory I have comes from five years‚Äô worth of Fridays standing at the side of the stage in Charlie‚Äôs, half a beer deep, 
[3/18]

"I have such a simple, pure nostalgia around the years I spent at Google in Mountain View, 2007-2012, that it almost figures in my mind like a childhood‚Äîa blur of grass and sun. I used to go out of my way to check out a weekly dodgeball game (that was a thing then). 
[2/18]

... For us on the Personality Team, we are still waiting to hear back about whether the company will respect our current contracts or convert us to full time positions. #ContractWorkerStories

...this happen. It proves that when we overcome what divides us, even a company as big as Google can be moved! 
However, even though these changes are an important step forward to acknowledging some of the needs of TVCs in general, there's still a long way to go. ...

UPDATE: Google sent an email to their employees a few hours ago informing us about changes they are making to improve working conditions for TVCs. These changes are significant and we're inspired by the thousands of full-time employees and TVCs who came together to make...

As of April 2, 2019, over 928 people and counting have signed this letter internally at Google. Most are full time employees. This is an historic show of support. There are nearly 122,000 TVCs (temps, vendors, and contract workers) at Google‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää54% of the workforce.

This is our team‚Äôs story, but we know the cycle of financial insecurity affects thousands of others: tell us your story: https://t.co/fOXFFfPZAN

‚Äî Coalition of FTEs and TVCs at Google

Finally, we demand that Google respect our humanity. Implement a policy that allows our FTE colleagues to openly empathize with us; allow our FTE colleagues to say thank you for the work we‚Äôve done.

We also demand that Google as a whole respect the work of contractors like those on the Personality Team. Convert contract workers to full-time employees, give us the benefits and stability we deserve.
We demand that Google respect and uphold our existing contracts. For those whose contract was shortened, we demand payment for the remaining length of the contracts.
As one of the most powerful companies in the world, Google plays a crucial role in setting global workplace standards. To truly be the company it claims to be, Google must live up to its values.

We believe that ethically scaling the growth of this company would require converting TVCs to FTE roles, not hiring and firing TVCs whenever it‚Äôs convenient. Workers, whether full time or on a contract at Google, deserve to have their agreements, rights, and dignity respected.

For years, Google has boasted of its ability to scale up/down very quickly, &been vocal about its ability to ‚Äúnavigate changes w/ agility.‚ÄùA whole team thrown into financial uncertainty is what scaling down quickly looks like for Google workers. This is the human cost of agility.
Our teammates were told to distance themselves from us at the moment when we were most in need‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjust so that Google could avoid legal responsibility.
During the process, our managers and the full-time workers on our team were silent. Google told them that offering support or even thanking us for years of work would make the company legally liable.
The only information the staffing agency delivered was that there had been a ‚Äúchange in strategy.‚Äù

But in the face of this reassuring messaging, our layoffs started in Seoul and moved by time-zone from London to NYC, & finally to CA. In some locations, our teammates were notified of their termination in group calls rather than individually.

"Also, moving forward, I want to emphasize that we focus on the 3 respects [respect the user, respect the opportunity, & respect each other] to ensure that each & every one of us feels that this is a team where you can bring your best selves to work & feel supported & included.‚Äù

In prior all-hands meetings, our leads assured us that even if the budget was cut, our contracts would be respected. Our senior manager wrote, ‚ÄúNo one else should be concerned for their own position as a result of [redacted] leaving or the reasons that have led to this. ...

Our existing contracts were nullified, contracts we‚Äôd been depending on as we planned our personal and financial futures. As an international team, changes in income and job status often mean uprooting our lives and our relationships to return to wherever home might be.
On March 8, International Women‚Äôs Day, nearly 82% of our 43-person contract team were told that by April 5 (in a few cases July 31) they would no longer have a job.

Most of us are contractors (TVCs), a group that makes up 54% of Google‚Äôs workforce. We work on two- to six-month contracts that are regularly renewed. Our term limit is two years. Many of us work without paid holidays or health care.

We‚Äôre the Personality Team. We‚Äôre responsible for the voice of Google ‚Äî the Google Assistant ‚Äî across the world. We are the human labor that makes the Assistant relevant, funny, and relatable in more than 50 languages.

Today, Google announced improved working conditions for TVCs, but "for us on the Personality Team, we are still waiting to hear back about whether the company will respect our current contracts or convert us to full time positions." #ContractWorkerStories 
https://t.co/SZi8USyDxc

We need to change the way the system works, above and beyond addressing the wrongs of those who work within the system. It is time for oversight, accountability, and for workers to truly have a say in decisions that affect their lives and the world around them.

When we walked out with twenty thousand colleagues in November, we included worker representation on the Board of Directors among our demands for this reason. We have all the evidence we need that Google‚Äôs leadership does not have our best interests at heart.

The lawsuits detail this behavior in action, & the past year provided many examples of the human collateral damage of such self-serving and unaccountable leadership. This needs to change. Those most at risk must be given a voice in decision making, & a seat at the table.
Currently, a small group of mostly white and male executives makes decisions that profoundly impact workers and the world beyond, with very little accountability.

The problems we face aren‚Äôt limited to coverups & an abdication of fiduciary duty. Google‚Äôs culture of racism, discrimination, & sexual harassment is not the result of a few individual bad actors‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs built into how the system works, & won‚Äôt be fixed without structural change.

...abdicated their fiduciary duty to Google as a whole and weakened the company by driving away qualified employees.

We agree. Anyone who enables abuse, harassment and discrimination must be held accountable, and those with the most power have the most to account for.

We welcome today‚Äôs shareholder lawsuits, and are grateful to those who brought them. Among other things, the lawsuits claim that by covering for and rewarding known sexual abusers such as Andy Rubin and Amit Singhal, Google‚Äôs Board of Directors and others in Google leadership ...

As a former Googler TVC, I fully support the TVCs, who desire fair treatment for the tireless work they contribute that allows Google to maintain its world-class operations and creative disruption across the industries. https://t.co/hRBje1QDAI

This must also include career growth, classes, and counseling opportunities like those offered to full-time workers.

Signed,
TVCs at Google

2. Access to company-wide information on the same terms as full-time employees. We want access to town hall discussions; all communications about safety, discrimination, and sexual misconduct; and a reinstatement of our access to internal forums like Google Groups.
This must also include a consistent and transparent conversion process to full-time employment, as well as adoption of a single badge color for all workers.

1. An end to pay and opportunity inequity for TVCs. We demand better pay and access to benefits that meet the full-time employee standard, including high-quality healthcare, paid vacations, paid sick days, holiday pay, family leave, and bonuses.
We reiterate the demands of the walkout, and make it clear that meeting these demands for all of us requires:

Google has the power‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the money‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääto ensure that we are treated equitably, with respect and dignity.

As we stated during the walkout, we need transparency, accountability, and structural change to ensure equity for all Google workers.

The excessive and unclear rules surrounding TVCs, in addition to the constant fear of our contracts not being renewed, makes it difficult for us to speak out. However, it is clear that we will continue to be mistreated and ignored if we stay silent.

We do essential work, from marketing, to running engineering teams, to feeding you and the rest of the Google staff‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall without fair benefits or recognition. Google cannot function without us.
Google has been increasingly hiring TVCs rather than full-time employees for all types of roles, resulting in a majority TVC workforce.
Google has been taking in record profits every quarter, with $9.2 billion in the last quarter alone. This money comes from the hard work of every single one of us, TVC and full-time alike.

Even when we‚Äôre doing the same work as full-time employees, these jobs routinely fail to provide living wages and often offer minimal benefits. This affects not only us, but also our families and communities.

TVCs are disproportionately people from marginalized groups who are treated as less deserving of compensation, opportunities, workplace protections, and respect. We wear different badges from full-time employees, which reinforces this arbitrary and discriminatory separation.
The exclusion of TVCs from important communications and fair treatment is part of a system of institutional racism, sexism, and discrimination.

TVCs were then excluded from a town hall discussion the following day. And when 20,000 full-time and TVC Google employees walked out to demand equal treatment for all workers, TVCs were again excluded from the company-wide discussion held a week later.

Google routinely denies TVCs access to information that is relevant to our jobs and our lives. When the tragic shooting occurred at YouTube in April of this year, the company sent real-time security updates to full-time employees only, leaving TVCs defenseless in the line of fire

As TVCs who took equal part in the walkout, your silence has been deafening.
Google‚Äôs mission is to ‚Äúorganize the world‚Äôs information and make it universally accessible.‚Äù But the company fails to meet this standard within its own workplace.

Dear Sundar,
As you know, 20,000 full-time and temporary, vendor, and contract workers (TVCs), recently walked out to protest ‚Äúdiscrimination, racism, sexual harassment and a workplace culture that only works for some.‚Äù

TVCs make up more than half of Google‚Äôs workforce, and we demand fair treatment. #GoogleWalkout

Even better, Airbnb ended forced arbitration for both sexual harassment AND discrimination, our full first demand! #GoogleWalkout https://t.co/brgnfFa2gb

When we said this is a global movement (https://t.co/G9fhg0h1ou), we didn‚Äôt just mean within Google ‚Äî it‚Äôs inspiring to see the effects of #GoogleWalkout spread past our company. https://t.co/5bln1N5MbC

We look forward to meeting with Google leadership in working to meet all of our demands.

#GoogleWalkout

While we‚Äôre thrilled to see progress on sexual harassment, we will not let up on the demands most urgent for women of color: an employee representative on the board, elevating the chief diversity officer, greater transparency on & an end to opportunity inequity at Google & beyond
This is a global movement, and the beginning of our continued work, not the end.

Demma Rodriguez: The process by which we build a truly equitable culture must center the voices of black women, immigrants&people of color‚Ää,‚Ää who too often pay the most in the face of these intersecting problems. We are committed to making this happen. True equity depends on it.

‚ÄúAnd they all have the same root cause which is a concentration of power & a lack of accountability at the top,‚Äù Stephanie said.
Sexual harassment is the symptom, not the cause. If we want to end sexual harassment in the workplace, we must fix these structural imbalances of power

In addition the company must address issues of systemic racism and discrimination, including pay equity and rates of promotion, and not just sexual harassment alone. These forms of marginalization function together to police access to power and resources.
...and giving full rights and protections to contract workers, our most vulnerable workers, many of whom are Black and Brown women.‚Äù

They are also largely people of color, immigrants, and people from working class backgrounds. Organizer Stephanie Parker said of the response, ‚ÄúWe demand a truly equitable culture, and Google leadership can achieve this by putting employee representation on the board...

This separates ‚Äòfull time‚Äô employees from contract workers. Contract workers make up more than half of Google‚Äôs workforce, and perform essential roles across the company, but receive few of the benefits associated with tech company employment.

However, the response ignored several of the core demands‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike elevating the diversity officer and employee representation on the board‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand troublingly erased those focused on racism, discrimination, and the structural inequity built into the modern day Jim Crow class system.

It also committed to more transparency in sexual harassment reporting, and will allow workers to bring representatives to meetings with HR. We commend this progress, and the rapid action which brought it about.
Today, Google made progress toward addressing these demands. The company followed Uber and Microsoft by eliminating forced arbitration in cases of sexual harassment.

The risk was calculated, and their demands were reasonable: these employees were asking for equity, dignity, and respect.

What they showed is that collective action works, and when we work together we can make change.

Last week, 20,000 Google employees and TVCs walked out to protest discrimination, racism, sexual harassment and a workplace culture that only works for some. By taking collective action, and joining a global movement, these workers took a risk.

Amazon‚Äôs success doesn‚Äôt need to be built at the expense of people‚Äôs health and right to a clean environment. Amazon is capable of thinking big and moving fast ‚Äî how long must we wait until we apply those strengths to boldly confront the climate crisis? 11/11

We must be ambitious and urge for transformative change within our company. Pollution from Amazon‚Äôs warehouses is harming people in cities such as in San Bernardino, CA, where communities like @CCAEJ are fighting back for their rights to clean air. 10/

Because of *our actions,* Amazon leadership completely changed course, and announced The Climate Pledge on Sept 19, one day before thousands of us walked out. This would not have happened if we all hadn't spoken up. However, there is so much more that can and must be done. 9/

In January 2019, Amazon leadership would not even share a date for releasing the company's carbon footprint. Since then, dozens of Amazon employees have spoken to the press about Amazon's climate impact and why it is so critical for us to stop harming the planet. 8/

Climate change is an issue affecting every human today and in the future. We are Amazon employees and the fact is clear: Amazon is contributing to climate change. We cannot be silent while our families and communities suffer. By speaking up, we can make the company better. 7/

‚Ä¶or the funding of lobbyists & think tanks who publicly deny climate change and/or actively work to suppress climate change legislation. Following this policy change, two of AECJ's leaders were warned to be silent or else face consequences, including termination of employment 6/

This policy change has nothing to do with sharing confidential company information; this change was made to explicitly forbid employees from speaking out about publicly available information, such as Amazon's partnerships with fossil fuel companies‚Ä¶ 5/

AECJ announced our participation in the 9/20 Global #ClimateStrike on Sep 4. On Sep 5, Amazon changed its communications policy stating that employees can no longer publicly identify as Amazon employees and say *anything* related to Amazon's business without prior PR approval. 4/
We must be able to speak up. Here is our press response to Amazon‚Äôs intimidation tactics. 3/ https://t.co/7DqhCw09Yf

A statement from us on continuing events around the NEOM deal: https://t.co/vckG0po0Es

These aren‚Äôt the only things in the unionbusting playbook, but we can expect companies to try to dismiss the concerns of organized game workers, turn players against them, and act as though companies and overpaid management are victims attacked by underpaid workers.

And finally - The loose framing of the entire statement as a timeline with stances interspersed into it is a (poor) attempt to establish a reasonable, factual-sounding narrative to combat the ‚Äúemotional‚Äù arguments (characterized as false) made by workers around labor conditions.

The focus on the social media campaign and ‚Äúfalse allegations‚Äù posted by writers and sandwiched between repeated allusions to previous attempts to negotiate is a framing that tries to position the campaign as unfair and workers going after/picking on the company

Including ‚Äúwe expect to see content delays‚Äù wrapped up in this statement is an equally brazen attempt to turn player sentiment against the workers and create the narrative ‚Äúcaring about workers and their welfare distracts everyone from doing their actual jobs‚Äù

‚ÄúWe attempted to negotiate individually‚Äù is a common and brazen tactic for dividing collective groups. Loud, highly involved organizers should expect to be fired. Folks perceived as quiet or on the fence should expect management to try to peel them off by appeasing them

Some things to note in the thread: 

The focus on ‚Äútheyre contractors not in-house employees‚Äù is b/c independent contractors dont have federal labor organizing protections in the US. We can expect to see a *lot* of that organizing in games, and have to be thoughtful about it.

Voltage management deleted their initial statement responding to the VOW organized writers, but it‚Äôs an important object lesson in how companies respond to workers organizing - it‚Äôs alive on the internet archive here: https://t.co/1iKrdyTtyS
